multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the British rule in India after 200 years?

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: A day in the life of the Oracle of Delphi - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the temple of Apollo in Delphi?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a place of worship for the Greek gods.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the center of the world, as identified by two eagles released by Zeus.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the location of the Oracle of Delphi, where the Pythia communicates Apollo's will.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a place of entertainment for the people of Delphi.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the Pythia in the temple of Apollo?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: It is a way to prepare the Pythia for a day of prophecy.

options.text: It is a way to honor the gods.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are the words of wisdom passed down from the Pythia to Aristonike.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the principles that guide the Oracle's prophecies.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a way to bring great riches and attention to Delphi.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way to determine the Oracle's prophecies.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way to cleanse the temple of any impurities.

title: Why do we have hair in such random places? - Nina G. Jablonski

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between human hair and animal fur?

options.label: A
options.text: Human hair is made of a different protein than animal fur.

options.label: B
options.text: Human hair is made of the same protein as animal fur, but grows in a different pattern.

options.label: C
options.text: Human hair and animal fur are made of the same stuff: filaments of the protein keratin.

options.label: D
options.text: Human hair is thicker and longer than animal fur.

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists believe early humans lost much of their coat?

options.label: A
options.text: To stay warm in cold climates.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect themselves from the sun.

options.label: C
options.text: To help their sweat evaporate faster.

options.label: D
options.text: To communicate with other animals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of hair on the tops of our heads?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect our sensitive scalps from the sun.

options.label: B
options.text: To keep our brains from overheating.

options.label: C
options.text: To communicate with other humans.

options.label: D
options.text: To distinguish identity from a distance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of apocrine glands in our bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce sweat that helps us cool down.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce oily, smelly secretions that help disperse.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce hair that grows in specific regions.

options.label: D
options.text: To produce nerve endings that convey signals of gentle touch.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of vellus hair that covers our bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide insulation and protect our skin.

options.label: B
options.text: To serve as a type of identification.

options.label: C
options.text: To repair damaged skin after injury.

options.label: D
options.text: To convey signals of gentle touch to the brain.

title: Can you solve the Trojan War riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: The Trojan War has been raging for 10 years, with neither Greeks nor Trojans prevailing. What is the reason for the 10-day truce agreed upon by both sides?

options.label: A
options.text: A divine omen has appeared, indicating a need for peace.

options.label: B
options.text: The Fates have advised that a 10-day truce will lead to the end of the war.

options.label: C
options.text: A prophecy has been made that a 10-day truce will result in 10 more devastating years of war if broken.

options.label: D
options.text: The gods and humans are tired and need a break.

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for the peace to prevail, according to the Fates' loom?

options.label: A
options.text: The Greek and Trojan camps must be arranged in a way that no Greek can reach any other Greek camp without passing through a Trojan camp.

options.label: B
options.text: The Greek and Trojan camps must be arranged in a way that no Greek can reach any other Greek camp without passing through a Trojan camp, and likewise for Trojans, plus neither side completely surrounds the other.

options.label: C
options.text: The Greek and Trojan camps must be arranged in a way that any Greek can reach any other Greek camp without having to pass through a Trojan camp, and likewise for Trojans.

options.label: D
options.text: The Greek and Trojan camps must be arranged in a way that any Greek can reach any other camp without having to pass through a camp of the other side.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first insight in solving the problem of keeping the peace?

options.label: A
options.text: To connect the Greek clumps without messing with the Trojan lines.

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with the thorny center space first.

options.label: C
options.text: To divide the problem into two sub-problems: connecting the Greek clumps and dealing with the center space.

options.label: D
options.text: To move all the Trojan camps to the perimeter of the field.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to thwarting the meddling Trojan camp that wants to break up the Greek connectivity?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the scheming camp precisely and move it to a different location.

options.label: B
options.text: To make at most two swaps with the same rules as before to thwart them.

options.label: C
options.text: To look for the Trojan camp that is somewhere within four grid spaces of the perimeter of the battlefield.

options.label: D
options.text: To move the Trojan camp to a different column.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle behind thwarting the meddling Trojan camp in the right arm?

options.label: A
options.text: To move the Trojan camp to a different row.

options.label: B
options.text: To move the Trojan camp to a different column.

options.label: C
options.text: To move either one of the two Trojan camps a column left into the square.

options.label: D
options.text: To move the Trojan camp to a different location on the grid.

title: Could you survive the real Twilight Zone? - Philip Renaud and Kenneth Kostel

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique adaptation of the hatchetfish that helps it navigate the Twilight Zone?

options.label: A
options.text: Its ability to change color to blend in with its surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: Its bioluminescent organs lining its belly that match the intensity and pattern of the faint light from the ocean's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: Its sharp teeth that allow it to catch prey quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to swim fast and escape predators.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process by which the ocean locks away carbon from the atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: The biological oxygen pump.

options.label: B
options.text: The biological carbon pump.

options.label: C
options.text: The ocean's carbon cycle.

options.label: D
options.text: The atmosphere's carbon sink.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the dragonfish is able to catch its prey in the dark depths of the ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: Its ability to produce red light that is visible to its prey.

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to emit red light from organs by its eyes that is invisible to its prey.

options.label: C
options.text: Its sharp teeth that allow it to catch prey quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to swim fast and escape predators.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the zone in the ocean where the hatchetfish begins its journey to the surface to feed?

options.label: A
options.text: The Photic Zone.

options.label: B
options.text: The Twilight Zone.

options.label: C
options.text: The Deep-Sea Zone.

options.label: D
options.text: The Ocean's Surface.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main source of food for the hatchetfish in the moment it reaches the Photic Zone?

options.label: A
options.text: Phytoplankton.

options.label: B
options.text: Small crustaceans and gelatinous zooplankton.

options.label: C
options.text: Dead animals and bits of skin.

options.label: D
options.text: Small grazers and phytoplankton.

title: Why rumors about vaccines spread— and how to rebuild trust - Heidi Larson

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason behind the distrust of the polio vaccine in northern Nigeria in 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: The mothers were particularly distrusting.

options.label: B
options.text: The local leaders, religious leaders, and local political leaders were distrusting due to the perceived Western conspiracy.

options.label: C
options.text: The vaccine was not effective in preventing polio.

options.label: D
options.text: The vaccine had a high risk of side effects.

multiple-choice.question: What did John Kennedy, a political scientist, find when he correlated data from 28 European countries with political opinion polling?

options.label: A
options.text: People who voted for populist parties were more likely to agree that vaccines were important, safe, and effective.

options.label: B
options.text: People who voted for populist parties were more likely to disagree that vaccines were important, safe, and effective.

options.label: C
options.text: There was no correlation between voting for populist parties and vaccine confidence.

options.label: D
options.text: The data was inconclusive.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why vaccines are highly susceptible to resistance and skepticism?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not effective in preventing diseases.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a high risk of side effects.

options.label: C
options.text: They are highly mediated by government and big business, which are low in trust ranks.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not easily accessible to the general public.

multiple-choice.question: What did the research find about the online conversations about vaccines in 2019?

options.label: A
options.text: The pro-vaccine groups were recruiting the undecided at a rate 500% faster than the anti-vaccine groups.

options.label: B
options.text: The anti-vaccine groups were recruiting the undecided at a rate 500% faster than the pro-vaccine groups.

options.label: C
options.text: There was no difference in the recruitment rate between the pro-vaccine and anti-vaccine groups.

options.label: D
options.text: The research did not find any significant difference in the recruitment rate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message that Ethan Lindenberg, an 18-year-old who posted about his mother's vaccine concerns on Reddit, wanted to convey to the public?

options.label: A
options.text: That people who refuse to vaccinate their children are bad parents.

options.label: B
options.text: That misinformation is the main problem, not a relationship problem.

options.label: C
options.text: That people who disagree with vaccines are not bad people, but rather loving parents who want the best for their children.

options.label: D
options.text: That vaccines are not effective in preventing diseases.

title: A brief history of the Israel-Palestine conflict

title: What causes migraines? - Marianne Schwarz

multiple-choice.question: What is one common experience of a migraine?

options.label: A
options.text: A throbbing, pounding headache.

options.label: B
options.text: Bright zigzagging lines across the field of vision.

options.label: C
options.text: Sensitivity to light.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.text: The cerebral cortex.

options.label: B
options.text: The brainstem.

options.label: C
options.text: The hypothalamus.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the trigeminal nerve in a migraine?

options.label: A
options.text: To transmit pain signals from the skin to the brain.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Should you donate your DNA to help cure diseases? - Greg Foot

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in developing new drugs for currently untreatable diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of funding

options.label: B
options.text: Difficulty in identifying the cause of the condition

options.label: C
options.text: Slow process of trial and error

options.label: D
options.text: Limited understanding of the molecular machines that keep the body going

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of DNA in identifying new therapeutic targets for diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the faulty proteins that cause a disease

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the genomes of people with similar conditions

options.label: C
options.text: To design new drugs to affect previously unknown protein targets

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze the health history data of individuals

multiple-choice.question: What are the three options researchers have when they identify a new therapeutic target for a disease?

options.label: A
options.text: To design a new drug to affect the target protein, to start a clinical trial, or to analyze the genetic data of individuals

options.label: B
options.text: To start a clinical trial, to design a new drug to affect the target protein, or to identify a previously linked disease that may be treatable

options.label: C
options.text: To identify a previously linked disease that may be treatable, to start a clinical trial, or to design a new drug to affect the target protein

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze the health history data of individuals, to design a new drug to affect the target protein, or to start a clinical trial

multiple-choice.question: Who may have access to an individual's genetic data and health history data for research purposes?

options.label: A
options.text: Only health care providers

options.label: B
options.text: Only private consumer genetic testing companies

options.label: C
options.text: Health care providers, private consumer genetic testing companies, and pharmaceutical companies

options.label: D
options.text: Individuals themselves

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of genomics in developing new drugs for currently untreatable diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the cost of developing new drugs

options.label: B
options.text: To speed up the process of developing new drugs

options.label: C
options.text: To identify new therapeutic targets for diseases

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: The electrical blueprints that orchestrate life - Michael Levin

multiple-choice.question: According to Mike Levin, what is one of the mysteries of biology that the traditional model of DNA as a blueprint for the body leaves unexplained?

options.label: A
options.text: How cells communicate with each other

options.label: B
options.text: How cells decide what to build in response to environmental cues

options.label: C
options.text: How the body achieves specific goals, such as building an embryo or regenerating a limb

options.label: D
options.text: How the body stores a map of what to do and how to rewrite that map

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the electrical signals that Mike Levin's research has revealed?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a way for cells to communicate with each other about their genetic makeup

options.label: B
options.text: They are a way for cells to communicate with each other about their environment and what to build

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way for cells to store a map of what to do and how to rewrite that map

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way for cells to control their behavior and decide what to build

multiple-choice.question: What is a xenobot, and what is its significance?

options.label: A
options.text: A xenobot is a type of cell that has been genetically edited to have a specific function, and it is significant because it can be used to study how cells communicate with each other

options.label: B
options.text: A xenobot is a novel organism that has been created by reprogramming cells to build a new body, and it is significant because it shows the amazing plasticity of cells

options.label: C
options.text: A xenobot is a type of machine that has been created using frog cells, and it is significant because it can be used to clean up toxins in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: A xenobot is a type of computer program that has been created to study how cells communicate with each other, and it is significant because it can be used to develop new treatments for disease

multiple-choice.question: According to Mike Levin, what is one of the potential applications of understanding how cells communicate with each other and rewrite their target morphologies?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing new treatments for cancer

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new treatments for birth defects

options.label: C
options.text: Developing new treatments for degenerative disease

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the bioelectric layer, according to Mike Levin?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a way for cells to communicate with each other about their genetic makeup

options.label: B
options.text: It is a way for cells to communicate with each other about their environment and what to build

options.label: C
options.text: It is a way for cells to store a map of what to do and how to rewrite that map

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way for cells to control their behavior and decide what to build

multiple-choice.question: B: How cells decide what to build in response to environmental cues
D: They are a way for cells to control their behavior and decide what to build
B: A xenobot is a novel organism that has been created by reprogramming cells to build a new body, and it is significant because it shows the amazing plasticity of cells
D: All of the above
C: It is a way for cells to store a map of what to do and how to rewrite that map

title: Meet the bluefin tuna, the toughest fish in the sea - Grantly Galland and Raiana McKinney

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the Atlantic bluefin tuna's ability to regulate its body temperature?

options.label: B
options.text: It has a countercurrent exchange mechanism that traps heat.

options.label: C
options.text: It is cold-blooded and depends entirely on the environment.

options.label: D
options.text: It has a specialized network of blood vessels that allows it to conserve heat.

options.text: 10 miles per hour

options.label: B
options.text: 20 miles per hour

options.label: C
options.text: 30 miles per hour

options.label: D
options.text: 40 miles per hour

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: 20-30 years

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: How to have constructive conversations - Julia Dhar

options.label: A
options.text: To attend a family wedding.

options.label: B
options.text: To talk to Americans about the election.

options.label: C
options.text: To visit his relatives.

options.label: D
options.text: To attend a business conference.

options.label: B
options.text: Belief perseverance.

options.label: C
options.text: Cognitive dissonance.

options.label: D
options.text: Self-fulfilling prophecy.

options.label: A
options.text: Curiosity conversation.

options.label: B
options.text: Constructive conversation.

options.label: C
options.text: Disagreement time travel.

options.label: D
options.text: Purposeful discussion.

multiple-choice.question: What is the technique used by the speaker's dad during his conversations with Americans, which involves asking the other person to articulate what kind of neighborhood, country, world, community, they want a year from now, a decade from now?

options.label: A
options.text: Disagreement time travel.

options.label: B
options.text: Future-focused conversation.

options.label: C
options.text: Constructive conversation.

options.label: D
options.text: Purposeful discussion.

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: How long should your naps be? - Sara C. Mednick

options.text: 30 minutes

options.label: B
options.text: 60 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: 90 minutes

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Stage 3

options.label: D
options.text: REM

options.text: Stage 2

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can you solve Dongle's Difficult Dilemma? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: According to the legend, what did the three galactic terraformers leave behind when they left the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: Three powerful golden hexagons and a note inviting adventurers to Dongle's castle.

options.label: B
options.text: Three powerful golden hexagons hidden within dungeons full of traps and monsters.

options.label: C
options.text: Three powerful golden hexagons, 5 silver hexagons, and a magic mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: Three powerful golden hexagons, 5 silver hexagons, and a note inviting adventurers to Dongle's castle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the strategy to win a matching trio of hexagons before the rival?

options.label: A
options.text: Spend big to try to win the golden hexagons outright and save as much as possible for silver.

options.label: B
options.text: Save as much as possible for silver and spend big on the golden hexagons.

options.label: C
options.text: Divide your gems into three groups of three and win, then force Gordon to spend enough on the golds to guarantee that you'll win on the silvers.

options.label: D
options.text: Bid everything you have left on the third gold hexagon and hope that Gordon will match you to block.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of having a one-gem advantage, such as 9 to 8, at the start of the silver auctions?

options.label: A
options.text: You can win three auctions by bidding 3 each time.

options.label: B
options.text: You can win two auctions by bidding 3 each time and have two gems left to beat Gordon with three bids of 3.

options.label: C
options.text: You can win three auctions by bidding 3 each time and have two gems left to beat Gordon with three bids of 3.

options.label: D
options.text: You can win three auctions by bidding 3 each time and have one gem left to beat Gordon with three bids of 3.

multiple-choice.question: What is the strategy to force Gordon's hand in the gold auctions so you go into silver with an advantage?

options.label: A
options.text: Bid at most 24 on the second gold hexagon and bid everything you have left on the third gold hexagon.

options.label: B
options.text: Bid everything you have left on the third gold hexagon and hope that Gordon will match you to block.

options.label: C
options.text: Bid 51 on the third gold hexagon and go into silver with a 51 to 48 advantage.

options.label: D
options.text: Bid at most 24 on the second gold hexagon and bid 25 every time to win three silvers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the bidding war if Gordon wins the second gold against your bid of 24?

options.label: A
options.text: You win the second gold and go into silver with a 51 to 48 advantage.

options.label: B
options.text: You win the second gold and go into silver with a 51 to 48 disadvantage.

options.label: C
options.text: You lose the second gold and go into silver with a 75 to 74 advantage.

options.label: D
options.text: You lose the second gold and go into silver with a 75 to 74 disadvantage.

title: The world’s most painful insect sting - Justin Schmidt

multiple-choice.question: Which insect is thought to possess the world's most painful sting?

options.label: A
options.text: Western honeybee

options.label: B
options.text: Tarantula hawk wasp

options.label: C
options.text: Rainforest-dwelling bullet ant

options.label: D
options.text: Ant that forages in rainforest canopies

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the entomologist who created the sting pain index?

options.label: A
options.text: Justin O. Schmidt

options.label: B
options.text: Charles Darwin

options.label: C
options.text: Lev Vygotsky

options.label: D
options.text: B.F. Skinner

multiple-choice.question: Why do honeybees usually die after stinging a victim?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their stingers are barbed and get stuck in the victim's skin

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are allergic to the venom they release

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too old and weak to survive

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to defend their colony

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the tarantula hawk wasp's sting?

options.label: A
options.text: To paralyze its victims and then feed on their bodies

options.label: B
options.text: To protect its colony from predators

options.label: C
options.text: To immobilize tarantulas so that it can lay its eggs on them

options.label: D
options.text: To gather food for its young

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the neurotoxic peptide found in the bullet ant's venom that makes the pain last so long?

options.label: A
options.text: Melittin

options.label: B
options.text: Poneratoxin

options.label: C
options.text: Venom toxin

options.label: D
options.text: Sting peptide

title: How compassion could save your strained relationships - Betty Hart

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker, Betty, is trying to convey in her talk about cancel culture?

options.label: A
options.text: That cancel culture is a necessary tool for maintaining social order.

options.label: B
options.text: That cancel culture needs to change and be replaced with compassion culture.

options.label: C
options.text: That cancel culture is a harmless trend that doesn't affect anyone.

options.label: D
options.text: That cancel culture is a form of social justice that benefits everyone.

multiple-choice.question: According to Betty, what are two premises that exist when we indulge in cancel culture?

options.label: A
options.text: We have to believe that we're right, and the other person has the ability to change.

options.label: B
options.text: We have to believe that we're right, and the other person does not have the ability to change.

options.label: C
options.text: We have to believe that we're wrong, and the other person has the ability to change.

options.label: D
options.text: We have to believe that we're wrong, and the other person does not have the ability to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of compassion that Betty finds fascinating?

options.label: A
options.text: Compassion means to avoid someone who is different from us.

options.label: B
options.text: Compassion means to suffer with someone, to suffer alongside them.

options.label: C
options.text: Compassion means to ignore someone who is different from us.

options.label: D
options.text: Compassion means to judge someone who is different from us.

multiple-choice.question: According to Betty, what can happen when we choose to suffer alongside someone who has a different belief system?

options.label: A
options.text: We may lose our friends and family who don't agree with us.

options.label: B
options.text: We may gain a new perspective and learn to appreciate their point of view.

options.label: C
options.text: We may become more entrenched in our own beliefs.

options.label: D
options.text: We may become indifferent to their opinions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway that Betty wants her audience to remember from her talk about cancel culture?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should always agree with others, even if we don't see eye to eye.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should be willing to suffer alongside others, even if we disagree with them.

options.label: C
options.text: That we should cancel anyone who disagrees with us.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should ignore anyone who disagrees with us.
